Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Computational Modeling of Protein Evolvability

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
While it is recognized that the molecular evolution of proteins is integral to the evolution of species, the physical mechanisms underlying protein evolution and the physical properties of proteins that facilitate evolution are not well understood. The objective of this CAREER project is to address these questions through the development and application of new theoretical models that rapidly and accurately capture the essential physics and chemistry relevant to the evolution of enzyme function. The approach will specifically involve modeling the effects of mutations on the stability of a native protein fold as well as the effects of mutation on catalytic efficiency. The application of these and other theoretical tools to informative model systems will form the basis for discovering physical-chemical features associated with molecular evolution. Examples of these features include the physical mechanisms underlying compensatory mutations as well as the role of protein stability and dynamics in facilitating transitions to new enzymatic activities.

This CAREER project represents an integrated and multidisciplinary educational and research approach, focused on using the laws of chemistry and physics to explain and predict fundamental evolutionary processes in biology. The new methods and new physical understanding of molecular evolution resulting from this project will have direct implications for a variety of fields including protein engineering and design, directed evolution, and nanotechnology. In addition to the impact of the research, the educational goals will impact future scientists by training undergraduate and graduate students to approach biological questions from a quantitative perspective. This objective will be partially realized through the development of a new undergraduate course in chemical biology and a new graduate level course in biophysical chemistry. In addition, this project will involve the development of a new interactive software package that will further establish, for students, the value of applying quantitative thinking to biological questions. The software will do this by allowing students to explore the connection between the physical properties of proteins and the biological function of proteins. The developed educational software will have a broad impact as it will be distributed freely to the public and will therefore be available to universities nationally and internationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological science rests on the foundation of Darwin’s principle of natural selection.  Evolutionary processes (at the molecular scale) are the source of drug resistance associated with infectious and genetic diseases, but also represent the basis of all biological evolution. As a consequence, studies illuminating biomolecular evolution have the potential for improving quality of life across the globe, as well as helping us to understand our own origins.

 The research in our group centers on the development and application of computational models for the purpose of characterizing (often in conjunction with experiment) the physical mechanisms and driving forces behind the evolution of proteins. This grant has helped to support numerous doctoral students (7) within our group who have made significant contributions to the field.  The research environment supported by this grant has also provided opportunities for numerous undergraduate students to participate in cutting-edge research while they earn their bachelors degrees. Together, doctoral and undergraduate students in our group have developed computational models to predict and characterize the impact of mutations on enzyme catalytic activity, conformational dynamics, and fold stability. These models connect biological evolution at the molecular scale with the underlying physics that drives this process of natural selection. Using these models, our group has discovered surprising new detailed mechanisms underlying drug resistance in HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) and a range of penicillin-resistant bacterial pathogens. These discoveries have opened the door to more effective antiviral and antibiotic drug discovery efforts.

 In collaboration with Prof. Weiguo Cao (Clemson University, Dept. of Genetics and Biochemistry), our team has also discovered the physical mechanisms underlying the evolution of substrate specificity in the UDG DNA repair enzyme superfamily – a collection of enzymes critical to maintaining the integrity of genomes throughout the tree of life. We have even contributed to the discovery of a new family of DNA repair enzymes within the UDG superfamily. The differentiation of enzymes into families and superfamilies is supported by a common evolutionary mechanism driving the development of new catalytic functions and increased biological complexity. In other words, these studies regarding specificity within the UDG superfamily are a window into the broader questions of evolution describing all living things.

 In addition to the research outcomes above, this grant has also facilitated the development of a new undergraduate course in Chemical Biology, which has now been integrated into the required curricula for 3 majors at Clemson University. The course introduces undergraduate students to the organic, inorganic, physical, and analytic chemistry of living organisms, with an emphasis on the chemistry of biomolecules including proteins, DNA, RNA, carbohydrates, and lipids. The course educates students in the foundations of chemical biology, but also provides students an opportunity to learn about the latest research in the field. At present, hundreds of undergraduates have been educated in this critical interdisciplinary field. In the future, refined course materials will be made freely available to anyone wishing to develop a similar course at any college or university in the country.

 The computational/theoretical basic research performed by our group, and supported by this grant, addressed scientific questions related to evolution that are fundamental to biological sciences. The results have a broad impact on our understanding of our own origins, as well as the future development of new medical treatments that address the modern challenge of drug resistance. These results have been made available through 12 published scientific articles, as well as numerous seminars at national conferences and universities. In addition, the results have also been disseminated to the public through a local community-wide science seminar series.
